title: James Blake opens up on his depression in powerful mental health essay
text:
Blake has written the piece for a new Penguin book on mental health (Picture: Dave Simpson/Getty Images)

James Blake has spoken candidly about his own experiences of battling depression and suicidal thoughts in a powerful written essay on mental health.

The Assume Form musician penned the piece, titled ‘How can I complain?’, for a new collection of writing about mental health from publishers Penguin.

In the essay, Blake says that he still carries ‘the shame of having been a straight white man who’s depressed and has experienced suicidal thoughts’, and recalls how he was bullied while at school and would often isolate himself from his fellow students.

‘During my school years I spent thousands of hours walking on my own with headphones on or playing piano in the practice rooms, often going there first to cry in private and then occasionally with a mind to play,’ Blake writes.

The London musician released his latest album Assume Form back in January (Picture: Matthew Baker/Getty Images)

‘Boys would see my sensitivity as weakness and, while I was sharp and quick-witted, I wasn’t sporty, which was my first mistake with them, I think.

‘I wondered for years whether I had some behaviour disorder. I still wonder. In any case, year upon year of capricious bullying and humiliation followed.’

The 31-year-old musician then discusses the impact his mental health has had on his music career, describing how he became ‘so self-obsessed and isolated that I wasn’t the success I seemed to be on paper’.

Blake reasons that a ‘chasm grew’ between his alias ‘who seemed in control of everything’ and ‘a man-child who for many years was hurting, spiralling, never leaving the house’.

Blake said he ‘wondered for years whether I had some behaviour disorder’ (Picture: Rebecca Sapp/WireImage)

Blake recalls that he eventually arrived at a point where he wasn’t ‘taking any care of [himself] what-so-ever until [he] was in a black depression, experiencing daily panic attacks, hallucinations and an existential crisis.

‘I was asking questions like “What is the point of me?” and saying I didn’t want to live.’

The London-born artist added that he still ‘wasn’t sure’ if he fully believed that he is ‘entitled to be depressed or sad at all, because I’m white and cisgender and male’.

‘Life for people like me is undoubtedly the easiest of any group,’ he posits. ‘But my privilege didn’t make me want to stick around, and it makes me feel even more embarrassed for having let myself go.’

Blake recently praised his girlfriend Jameela Jamil for her work on Assume Form (Picture: SplashNews.com)

Blake also credits in the essay the support of his girlfriend Jameela Jamil, who yesterday spoke about her own mental health and recalled the time she attempted to take her own life six years ago.

‘I urge you to hang on just a bit longer and ask for help if you need it,’ Jamil wrote on Twitter in a post marking World Mental Health Day.

‘Because things can turn around. I promise.’
